description.narrative: Development Effectiveness.
independent political entity

- Number of national and regional plans using newly available data - Availability of up to date gender disaggregated poverty data - Clear institutional set-up for planning in place at the national and regional level - Number of national and regional plans with specific policy to reduce negative socio-environmental impacts of private investment and capacity building with regulatory tools for implementation - Standard Operating Procedures and preferences for aid modalities in place - AIMS developed and in place

comment.narrative: - 0 national and regional plans using newly available data - Last IHCLA survey conducted in 2010 and no system of national accounts - Planning system centralized at the moment and to shift to an integrated planning and budget system - Limited policy and laws, and capacity and regulatory tools reflected in national and regional plans to manage socio-environmental impacts of private investment - No standard operating procedure/regulatory manual in place for managing aid modalities - No Aid Management System (AIMS) in place

description.narrative: Capacity of government institutions enhanced to develop and implement administrative and civil service reforms that promote responsiveness and efficiency
The public administration reform output aims to improve responsiveness of the public administration.
independent political entity

- Number of pilot public administration reform activities developed (Indicator 01) - Number of opportunities where government counterparts can learn from other public administration reform experiences, especially south-south experiences (Indicator 02) - Multi-year UCSB training programme developed for civil servants (Indicator 01) - Effectiveness of the usage of equipment provided to training institutes (as measured through surveys completed by training beneficiaries) (Indicator 02) - Number of reports and pieces of information on the civil service posted on the UCSB website (Indicator 03)

comment.narrative: - 0 (TBC) pilot public administration reform activities developed (Indicator 01) - 0 (TBC) learning and south-south cooperation opportunities within government on public administration and public administration reform initiatives (Indicator 02) - No Multi-year UCSB training programme developed for civil servants (Indicator 01) - Training environments and equipment are not in line with modern international practice (Indicator 02) - TBD. Number of reports and pieces of information on the civil service posted on the UCSB website (Indicator 03)

description.narrative: Parliament at Union levels and selected state/ region levels perform their functions.
Parliamentary Support
independent political entity
Elections - elections

- 2.1 Percentage of surveyed committees at the Union level reporting satisfaction with administrative, technical support, and procedural advice provided by staff. - 2.2 Strategic plan used to guide the vision and mission of the parliament in regards to legislation, representation, and oversight functions. - 2.3 Percentage of MPs and staff at the union level reporting improved core and specialized skills as a result of Learning Centre Trainings. - 2.4 Number of committees at the union level that request information and/or research from research and library services . - 2.5 Percentage of target users/ units at the union level using the ICT system for information management, research, and communication. - 2.6 Increase in the number of hearings by targeted committees at the union level that scrutinize policies regarding the protection of the rights of women, children, and vulnerable groups. - 2.7 Number of committees at the union level conducting outreach activities (e.g. field visits, community consultations, and information bulletins). - 2.8 Strategic plan used to guide the vision and mission of selected state and regional parliaments in regards to legislation, representation, and oversight functions. - 2.9 Number of committees in selected state and region Hluttaws holding broad consultations on draft legislation. - 2.10 Number of committee hearings related to oversight of state and regional governments. - 2.11 Number of hluttaw dialogues on peace building with local communities and stakeholders. - 2.12 Percentage of MPs and staff members in selected state and regional Hluttaws reporting benefitting from each capacity development activity during a post-training assessment.

comment.narrative: - 2.1 0% of committees surveyed; there is no evaluation of administrative, technical support, and procedural advice. - 2.2 No strategic development plan. - 2.3 There is no Learning Centre, and no strategy for the long term development and training of MPs and staff. - 2.4 No research and library services exist, so no committees can request information and research. - 2.5 No ICT system used for information management, research, and communication - 2.6 There are no hearings by targeted committees regarding the protection of the rights of women, children and vulnerable groups. - 2.7 No outreach activities conducted by committees - 2.8 No strategic development plans in place at region and state level. - 2.9 Consultations organized but no broad participation of stakeholders. - 2.10 None - 2.11 State and regional parliaments do not play any role in peace building and do not play a function in facilitating dialogue (No dialogues held.) - 2.12 0%- region state parliaments did not receive training by UNDP in 2013.

- 2.1 25% of surveyed committees. - 2.2 Strategic Development Plan referred to in Parliaments work plans and capacity related support and assistance from outside. - 2.3 30% of MPs and staff surveyed. - 2.4 Six committees. - 2.5 25% of target users/units. - 2.6 Three hearings by target committees. - 2.7 Two committees. - 2.8 Strategic plan is used in 50% of selected state and regional parliaments. - 2.9 Two committees - 2.10 Two committees. - 2.11 No target; preparatory work completed. - 2.12 50% of responding MPs and staff members.

The Parliament continued to show leadership of its reform process, launching a Learning Centre and expanding capacity of committees and committee staff. - 2.1 22% of MPs reported satisfaction. UNDP's survey of 60 MPs shows that services have advanced and expanded over time in a process strongly supported by MPs, but that MPs feel services currently available in the Hluttaw still need to be strengthened. - 2.2 Departmental workplans showing the practical steps towards the achievement of the strategic plan, with indicators and targets, developed and implemented jointly by staff and MPs. Development partners refer to Strategic Plan. - 2.3 94% of 278 surveyed staff trained in the Learning Centre report improvement. Learning Centre trained 1,099 people in 13 subjects since launch in March (most towards the end of the year, so haven't been surveyed.) - 2.4 5 of 100 surveyed MPs used research services for drafting and reviewing bills. The survey showed that most MPs highly value the research services offered and their political impartiality. - 2.5 No users are yet using the system, as the installment of ICT infrastructure has not been completed. - 2.6 6 mock hearings by target committees held. MPs engaged in consultations on the legal aid law, child law, and prevention of violence against women law. - 2.7 and 2.9 work in these areas was post-poned at committees request. - 2.8 Strategic plan developed in 5 parliaments. - 2.10 4 Committees from 4 parliaments held mock hearings. - 2.11 Not done. - 2.12 97% of 44MPs and staff found technical support and trainings useful. 10 MPs and staff were female.

title.narrative: Rule of Law and Access to Justice

description.narrative: Justice institutions and legal framework improved to ensure Rule of Law and Access to Justice for all with a specific focus on vulnerable groups.

title.narrative: Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice
Rule of Law and Access to Justice

description.narrative: Rule of Law and Access to Justice.
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

- 3.1 Number of mid-level officials from justice institutions (the Supreme Court and Attorney Generals Office) trained to develop and deliver training programs to meet the needs of justice sector reform. - 3.2 Number of university law departments that include clinical legal education in their curricula. - 3.3 Percentage of trainees (in both justice institutions and law departments) reporting the relevance of training for practical use. - 3.4 Number of actions taken by justice institutions to promote consultative and participatory legislative development. - 3.5 Use of new approaches to raise legal awareness of vulnerable groups in targeted areas. - 3.6 Number of examples in which justice sector actors have responded to the priority justice needs of vulnerable people (e.g. action in specific cases or development of protocols/strategies) - 3.7 Number of justice sector policies/plans initiated to improve coordination on crosscutting justice concerns. - 3.8 Justice sector institutional capacity development plans produced and steps toward implementation undertaken

comment.narrative: - 3.1 None there was no system for training of trainers (TOT) - 3.2 No university law department in Myanmar has a clinic legal education in its curricula. - 3.3 Justice sector actors have expressed the need for knowledge and skill based-training. - 3.4 There have been no consultative and legislative participatory developments; legal drafting is closed. - 3.5 There are no special measures designed to increase legal awareness of vulnerable groups. - 3.6 Mapping study (December 2013) documents provide few examples in which justice sector actors have responded to priority needs of vulnerable people (e.g. in land registration disputes or cases of SGBV). - 3.7 None. There are no justice sector policies/plans which promote coordination on crosscutting justice concerns. - 3.8 No existing capacity development plans for justice sector actors (initial milestones to be identified once capacity development plans developed).

- 3.1 Fifteen, through at least five mentoring sessions to support (i) curriculum development on fair trail principles and (ii) teaching skills. - 3.2 Four university law departments. - 3.3 60% of justice actors trained by UNDP and law departments reporting relevance of training for practical use. - 3.4 Two consultations. - 3.5 One or more of the following approaches utilized: mobile clinics, multiple reinforcement, small-group training, and community-based support groups; and at least totalling six times per target area per year. - 3.6 Two examples of justice sector actor responses. - 3.7 One policy/plan initiated. - 3.8 One capacity development plan from the second justice institution.

'- 3.1 Training departments in the Union Attorney General's Office and Office of the Supreme Court of the Union benefit from mentoring on curriculum development, but no training of trainers on fair trial standards conducted. - 3.2 18 universities apply Clinical Legal Education teaching modalities and principles in parts of curricula. - 3.3 72% of 25 TOT trainees, 87% of 57 CSO representative trainees, and 100% of 12 law professors report improved skills as a result of Rule of Law Centres and Clinical Legal Education programmes, noting relevance of training. - 3.4 Three national consultations held on draft laws (legal aid, prevention of violence against women, child law), and a handbook for legislative development drafted that makes provision for public participation in future drafting processes. - 3.5 Small group training and community forums used to raise legal awareness. 4 local level roundtables discussed draft laws and women's rights issues; 2 Rule of Law Centres trained academics and civil society in Shan, Mandalay and Kachin on justice issues over a 6 month period, including through mock trials. - 3.6 Three draft laws address justice needs (Legal Aid, Prevention of Violence Against Women, and the Child laws). In Shan and Mandalay, justice actors discussed gender-based violence with communities, gaining insight on how to better respond to the needs of vulnerable groups. - 3.7 2. UAGO Strategic Plan developed through a participatory process, and launched. UAGO and the OSCU met jointly with the Central Statistics Office to discuss a coordinated justice sector ICT strategy for case information management. - 3.8 UAGO Strategic Plan includes objectives for reviewing and strengthening training curricula. UNDP and IDLO are supporting the UAGO and OSCU to conduct training curriculum reviews in line with the training needs of judicial officers, law officers and institutional staff.

Indicator 01. # of women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations (All Areas) Indicator 02. % of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 03. # of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 04. # persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 05. % Increase in # of households reporting more than 5 occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 06. % of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 07. % of trained participants who successfully apply the knowledge and skills on social cohesion gained from training initiatives into their work. (disaggregated by gender) Indicator 08. % of people surveyed who report that their level of trust toward others have increased as a result of their participation in training initiatives (disaggregated by gender) Indicator 09 . % Households purchasing technologies reporting and improved perception of women and youth as a result of market transactions facilitated by the programme (diaggregated by men and women) Indicator 10. # of Early Recovery strategies developed and implemented (national, Rakhine and Kachin); Indicator 11. Early Recovery principles integrated in humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans;

comment.narrative: Indicator 01. 25:100 women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations Indicator 02. 0% of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support Indicator 03. % of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support Indicator 04. 300,000 persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure Indicator 05. 31% of households reporting more than 5 occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months Indicator 06. 0% of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions Indicator 07. 0% of trained participants who successfully apply the knowledge and skills on social cohesion gained from training initiatives into their work. Indicator 08. 0% of people surveyed who report that their level of trust toward others have increased as a result of their participation in training initiatives Indicator 09 . 0% Households purchasing technologies reporting and improved perception of women and youth as a result of market transactions facilitated by the programme (diaggregated by men and women) Indicator 10. No Early Recovery strategies developed and implemented (national, Rakhine and Kachin); Indicator 11. 0 Early Recovery principles integrated in humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans;

Indiactor 1. 40:100 women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations (All Areas) Indicator 2. 70% of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support Indicator 3. 80% of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support Indicator 4. 300,000 persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure Indicator 5. 46.5 households (50% increase) reporting more than 5 occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months Indicator 6. 50% of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 7. NA Indicator 8. NA Indicator 9. NA Indicator 10. Recovery Network Strategy developed for target locations (Rakhine and Kachin). Indicator 11. Integration of ER principles in at least 2 humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans

Support reached up to 196,571 people in 113 villages in Mon, Kachin, Kayin, Rakhine and Shan states. Key interventions included support to rural and flood and conflict-affected communities in Rakhine; support to returnees and host-communities in Kachin, and the roll-out of a pilot initiative to improve market-based livelihood opportunities for rural communities by increasing their access to innovative technologies in Mon, Kayin and Shan. In 2015, Capital assistance reached 113 persons (48% women); 23,107 (52% women) persons benefitted from access to new infrastructure; and 40 young entrepreneurs (65% women) have established businesses selling fuel-efficient and renewable energy products in their communities. By end-2015, up to 89% of those receiving capital assistance for agriculture, livestock and fisheries reported an increase in income and 100% of those receiving capital assistance for enterprises reported sustaining their enterprise, both 6 months following the receipt of support. The Programme also reported 47 female CBO members for every 100, an increase from a baseline of 25 persons, and 82% households reporting an increase in opportunities for interaction between different communities, an increase from a baseline of 46.5 households. While ongoing in 2016, 589 persons from a cross-section of local government, CSOs and none-state actors (ethnic armed organizations) have developed their capacities to train local stakeholders in six states.
